history.content:
162 teaches you how to work in a group to design, implement, and debug a complex system.

A career in software engineering consists almost entirely of working in a group to design, implement, and debug complex systems.

-----

I also think the topics and concepts taught in 162 are very applicable to software engineering in general. As an example, manually handling race conditions via locking is a good concept to know. Also, the way in which the class forces you to write code just makes you a better programmer imo.

162 teaches you how to work in a group to design, implement, and debug a complex system.

A career in software engineering consists almost entirely of working in a group to design, implement, and debug complex systems.

children.subject: I would definitely recommend taking 170 before 162 (and before most other upper divs for that matter since 170 is probably the most useful for interviews). With that said, 162 is definitely a class you can take later on. I'm graduating this semester and I also took 162 this semester and feel like I was fine without it earlier on.

Is it important to take 162 before most of your other upper div CS classes or could I take it my last semester (I’m graduating in three years)? I am planning to take 170 before everything else. Is it more important to take 162 first, and if I do that, would it be okay to take 170 last or should that be in the middle?

history.content: Can someone explain why the course is so important for a career in Software Engineering
history.subject: 162 Considered Most Important Upper Div
